title: Lamb Pot Roast with Cloves, Roman Style
introduction: Cloves, called chiodi di garofalo in Italian, lend a distinctive flavor to this lamb pot roast from the Roman countryside. Traditionally made with boned and rolled lamb shoulder, this comforting dish can also be prepared using leg of lamb.
ingredients: 3 1/2 pounds boneless lamb shoulder roast, rolled and tied
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
A pinch of crushed red pepper
1 cup meat broth or canned beef broth
instructions: Stick the cloves into the lamb. Sprinkle the meat all over with salt and pepper.
In a large casserole dish or Dutch oven, heat the oil over medium heat. Add the lamb and cook, turning it with tongs, until browned on all sides, about 20 minutes.
Scatter the onion, celery, carrot, parsley, and red pepper around the meat. Add the wine and cook until it evaporates, about 2 minutes. Add the tomato puree and broth. Reduce the heat to low.
Cover and cook, turning the meat occasionally, for 2 1/2 to 3 hours or until tender when pierced with a fork.

Transfer the meat to a cutting board. Cover and keep it warm. Skim the fat from the pan juices. Pour the vegetables and pan juices into a food processor or blender and puree until smooth. Taste and adjust seasoning. Pour the sauce into a medium saucepan and reheat it over low heat. If it is too thin, simmer it until reduced. Slice the lamb and serve hot with the sauce.
